reasoning: The critique targets a specific, later-stage support claim: that under moral uncertainty, “fairest/plausible” intertheoretic comparisons tend to make the overall stance fussy (by giving unbounded views more weight). This is relevant but not load-bearing for the paper’s main ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion, which is also supported by earlier sections (fragility/product-of-factors argument; fussiness across many value functions). So centrality is moderate-low. Strength is moderate: pointing out anchor/normalization sensitivity is a real vulnerability in the paper’s moral-uncertainty upshot, and it plausibly downgrades the claim from “fairest methods are fussy” to “some plausible methods are fussy,” but it does not show that the paper’s preferred approaches are incoherent or that robustness is impossible—just under-argued. Correctness is high: it accurately identifies affine freedom, dependence on contentious pairwise comparability claims, and the governance-relevance of robustness; it does not make obviously false technical claims. Clarity is high: the attacked claim, mechanism (anchoring), and implication are explicit. Dead weight is low. It stays focused on a single parameter-sensitivity issue.
title: Intertheoretic comparison methods are too anchor-sensitive to robustly support fussiness
